The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. The present paper provides a categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators. This addresses a question raised in these programs. The result is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a long-standing problem in the foundations of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. To understand the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content that is characteristic of the parasitic Myxozoa, we compared the genomes of two myxozoans to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals, and that the parasite has lost many genes involved in development and cell–cell communication. These findings suggest that the parasitic lifestyle was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results also suggest that the transition from a free-living to a parasitic lifestyle was accompanied by a reduction in the complexity of the body plan. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of interferon. Our results provide a new insight into the mechanism of action of SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food supply is threatened by climate change. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase dramatically, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for more comprehensive species-level diet analyses in future studies of large mammal communities. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off employees and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to supporting the survival of small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the debris, which is dominated by small particles. These particles are subject to fast fragmentation in the ocean interior, which removes them from the surface. This sink may be the missing link to explain the low load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface.

The age of the Solar System is a key issue in astronomy. The age of the Solar System is also a key issue in astrobiology, because the age of the Solar System is the age of the oldest material in the Solar System. The age of the oldest material in the Solar System is the age of the oldest material that was available for the origin of life. We determined the age of the oldest material in the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded dramatically. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its fishing effort. It is a valuable resource for understanding the impact of the global fishing fleet on ocean resources and the environment. (Show more)

The ability to increase the number of offspring produced by a single female is a defining characteristic of all species. This is particularly true for humans, who have the ability to produce many more offspring than the average animal. This ability is the result of a complex interplay between the mother and the environment. Here, we show that the ability to increase the number of offspring produced by a single female is a common feature of all species, and that it is the result of the mother’s ability to increase the number of offspring produced by a single female. This is a fundamental property of all species, and one that is likely to be important for understanding the evolution of all species.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the substantia nigra and the dorsal striatum. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the most toxic form of the protein. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be of great importance for the treatment of MSA, which is currently incurable. (Show more)

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation, and regulating blood pressure. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, and to be highly efficient in the transmission of information. Here, we show that the network is highly efficient, and that the cells are connected in a way that allows for rapid communication between them. These findings provide insight into the design of the endothelial network and the mechanisms by which it is able to control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic, responding to it, and learning from it. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to many.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channel and that it is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for natural products to be discovered from the microbiome is vast. This study provides a resource of natural products from anaerobic fungi that could be used as a starting point for the discovery of new compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups and is influenced by personality traits. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis method to design mechanical structures with arbitrary responses under large deformations. The structures are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The materials are digitally synthesized to achieve the target responses, and the structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular material distributions. Within the structures, different materials seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of evolution. The hemoglobin system is under the control of two major developmental programs, one of which is the heterochronic program that sets the age of onset of adult hemoglobin. The other program is the evolution of hemoglobin levels in response to environmental conditions. Here we show that a gene involved in the heterochronic program, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), is involved in the control of hemoglobin levels in humans. This finding has implications for the evolution of hemoglobin levels and the control of lifespan. It also has implications for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, which are highly prevalent in human cancer, are resistant to ferroptosis. This resistance is mediated by a lipogenesis program driven by sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and monounsaturated fatty acids, which are central regulators of lipid metabolism. These findings suggest that ferroptosis can be exploited as a therapeutic strategy for cancer, and that combination of ferroptosis induction with mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising approach for cancer therapy. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. It also provides a rationale for the development of new drugs that target the Ca2+ signaling machinery. This may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in the Pacific Northwest, but that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing the long-term declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP is a science-based policy, and we show that the policy’s success is linked to the implementation of science-based management practices. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. We also show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the long-term declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. This is a major challenge for the policy, and we discuss the need for continued monitoring and adaptive management. Our findings are important for the design of other policy instruments for the conservation of biodiversity.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here is a promising approach for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. Here we show that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can also reduce the amount of sleep and increase the time to fall asleep. These effects are likely to have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the impact hypothesis has been challenged by the discovery of magnetic grains and microspherules at the YDB. These grains are thought to be extraterrestrial in origin, but we show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of terrestrial origin. We also show that the spherules at the YDB are of impact origin and are consistent with the source being in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the development of autoimmunity and in different systemic diseases is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is not limited to early life, but is also important in the adult.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetles, including the impact of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a combination of genomic and fossil data. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in multiple stages, including low rates of extinction over a long period of time, the codiversification of beetles and plants, and the evolution of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of cultural evolution experiments. They also have implications for the design of education and training systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with a twofold decreased risk for AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD risk. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization from the molten outer core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human brain. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning approaches can be used to make accurate predictions about the neural and behavioral responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism in the language comprehension system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is known to be unstable. We show that this instability is not due to the lack of stability of the mathematical models used in DL, but rather to the lack of stability of the algorithms used to train the models. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can compute stable neural networks with great accuracy. This is a major step toward the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a textbook example of how the human brain can be misled by the very information it is designed to process. This paper discusses the design flaws of a classic psychological experiment, which is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The paper also discusses the cognitive biases that led to the flawed design, and the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the leprosy bacillus. We found that the two organisms are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation, and that they are still capable of causing similar diseases. This study provides a framework for future studies of the evolution of leprosy and its causative agents. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question of quantum physics. It is also of great practical importance, as it is at the heart of the quantum speedup. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is valid for both interacting and noninteracting systems, and it is exact in the case of integrable systems. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid response to combat the disease. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to do so. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by the University of Oxford in collaboration with the University of the Witwatersrand. The vaccine is based on a temperature-sensitive mutant of SARS-CoV-2, which is able to replicate efficiently at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is being tested in a relevant animal model and is expected to be ready for human trials by the end of 2020.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we describe a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of this disease. It also provides a framework for understanding the history of other diseases spread by human ectoparasites.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, to get a less biased picture of the evolutionary paths leading to high cognitive power, we need to compare brains not by mass but by numbers of neurons, which are their basic computational units. This study reconstructs the evolution of brains across amniotes by directly analyzing neuron numbers by using the largest dataset of its kind and including essential data on reptiles. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, current inhibitors of TRAP1 are not specific, and thus cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, a protein that is also a target of cancer therapy. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. ADF is thought to do so by severing the filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF severes filaments is not known. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on the filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is used by other proteins that are involved in the disassembly of actin filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a new way. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia, with a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of the genetic contributions across the island shows that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the extent to which it occurs in the real world is unclear. In an experiment with people who use Facebook, we show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. They also suggest that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, which may have implications for the design of social media platforms and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and the presence of chemical modifications can have a profound impact on translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a chemical modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and that this can have a modest impact on translation. This work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation and may have implications for understanding disease-related mutations. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in the fossil record, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this disease. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human body is unknown. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the innate immune response of the host cell.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the surface-attached type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this signal is used to regulate the expression of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. This is the first report of a bacterial mechanosensory system that uses the mechanical activity of the cell surface as a signal.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water quality has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of peer-reviewed studies that evaluates the presence of pesticides in surface water and how this contamination affects aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This study highlights the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. These results have implications for the protection of surface water quality and the conservation of aquatic biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread to many animal species, including deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer, and the identification of multiple lineages of the virus in both deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study provides a model for the rapid detection of animal reservoirs of SARS-CoV-2, and the potential for the virus to spread between humans and animals. This information is critical for the development of effective public health strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus. (Show more)

This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the challenges of building them, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources. We conclude that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also conclude that the environmental and social impacts of dams are not being adequately addressed. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD patients. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary toxic species in AD, and that neurons are the primary source of Aβ in the brain. We demonstrate that neurons are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ, and that this Aβ is the primary toxic species in the brain. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response in AD. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of this species. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. The majority of the chicken bones belong to adult individuals, and the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones is consistent with the assumption that the species was exploited for meat. The results are supported further by an extensive survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of the chicken. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details of its mechanism are important for understanding its function. Here we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold in two distinct steps.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for rapid degradation of the capped transcripts. In Escherichia coli, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that a second enzyme, RppH, is activated by disulfide stress and assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts. Unexpectedly, RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in cancer, where it has been shown to be a key metabolite in the arginine deprivation mechanism. This study may also have implications for other diseases characterized by immune dysfunction. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for assessing the impact of human activities on the global biomass.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can be driven out of equilibrium and then evolve in a self-sustaining manner. The driving force is the system’s tendency to return to equilibrium. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of relaxation times, and the system’s behavior is described by a critical exponent. The critical behavior is robust, and it is found in a wide variety of systems. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is even more so, as there are no known antifungal drugs. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, and demonstrate its antifungal activity and mode of action. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction during sexual reproduction. Despite the importance of this interface, we know little about the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of sperm and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular hand-off between males and females. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by interacting with glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα). Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is a significant finding, as it provides a method for measuring the kinetics of receptor−ligand interactions in the bulk phase. This method can be applied to other systems. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies of the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Observations of ACI are challenging because of the complexity of the system. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The instrument is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the instrument’s capability to investigate ACI. The observations provide substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This is a significant contribution to the field.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has changed over geological time, and the temperature of the surface of the Earth at the time of life’s origin is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. Here, we provide evidence for a decrease in the temperature of the Earth’s surface over geological time.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can exhibit slow C-type inactivation/recovery and that the extents and rates of C-type inactivation/recovery inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery in K+ channels. It also provides a possible mechanism for the BK channel’s normal closing. (Show more)

Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people each year. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the RBC in the process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, and that the parasite is able to influence the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This would represent a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a promising material for energy storage. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity, and its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized by applying strain, and that the electronic properties of diamond can be controlled by strain engineering. This work provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, and it will be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to process language by first parsing it into a tree-like structure of phrases. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain actually builds such structures. Here, we show that the brain encodes the structure of sentences by merging words into phrases. We provide evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More generally, our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to identify the structure of language. This parser is likely to be a fundamental component of all language-processing systems.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in development and disease. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. We believe that this study will help to elucidate the mechanism of redundant genes and will be useful in the study of other redundant gene pairs.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is poorly understood. Here we describe a circuit that is critical for this process. We show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated animals. This circuit is composed of neurons in the lateral hypothalamus and the ventral tegmental area, and it is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is a key trait for plants. However, the ability to fix nitrogen is limited to a few plant species, and the process is not sustainable. We have developed a synthetic plant-bacterial system that allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen to cereals, thus improving their growth and yield. This would be a sustainable solution to the nitrogen problem. This work is a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial system that could be used to deliver nitrogen to cereals, thus improving their growth and yield. This would be a sustainable solution to the nitrogen problem. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to inform forest monitoring and management, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced forest loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global problems. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused billions of dollars in economic losses. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. In this study, we report the design and engineering of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing and elicits a strong immune response. The engineered protein is expected to be a valuable addition to the global vaccine arsenal.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is caused by mutations in anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), which is also involved in the development of other tissues. Recently, we identified secreted small ALKAL proteins as ligands for ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). Here, we show that these ligands are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and that they activate ALK/LTK receptors. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALKALs in the development of human tissues and suggest a therapeutic target for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of infectious disease. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes that provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of this pathogen. We show that the emergence of plague was a multistep process, and that the pathogen underwent a series of gene losses during its evolution. We also show that the plague lineage underwent a period of rapid dispersal across Eurasia, a trend not observed in other pathogens. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its relationship to its reservoir host, the flea. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM was associated with support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 1.1 billion ha of natural grassland worldwide. This has resulted in the release of massive amounts of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, which is a major contributor to climate change. The management of agricultural lands can mitigate this C loss, but the effects of different practices on soil C dynamics are highly uncertain. We show that the management of annual cropping systems with legumes and manure can increase soil C storage, whereas the management of pastures with rotational grazing can increase soil C storage and the use of soil C by soil microbes. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the restoration of grasslands worldwide. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to cause future pandemics. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery efforts and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the chemical composition of the reward. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, and show that the same enzymes are involved in the production of red nectar in the distantly related hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. These findings suggest that the red nectar trait is convergent, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, which have shaped the genetic structure of the population today. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the Germanic tribes and the arrival of the Vikings is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. The collective genetic ancestry of this group suggests an origin in southeastern Europe, which is in contrast to the genetic ancestry of men, who are mostly of northern and central European origin. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent and control future zoonotic outbreaks. This article is protected

We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the most important proteins is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), which is involved in many processes, including DNA replication. In this study, we investigated the interaction between the lagging strand DNA polymerase δ and PCNA. We found that the interaction between the two proteins is not stable, which is important for the activity of the polymerase. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanism of lagging strand DNA replication. It also provides a basis for the development of new drugs that can be used to treat cancer. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this work, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

Urban change is a complex phenomenon that is difficult to study. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study urban change in other cities and in other countries. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners. We also hope that our method will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study urban change.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is an anti-interleukin-6 receptor antibody, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a new treatment option for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The ability of fungi to control copper levels is poorly understood, and the mechanisms of copper homeostasis are not well established. Here we report the identification of a copper-binding metabolite of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, and demonstrate that this metabolite has a significant impact on copper homeostasis and on the ability of A. fumigatus to control the copper status of competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the control of metal homeostasis and the ability of fungi to control the microbial environment. This knowledge will be useful for the development of antifungal and antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

Silica is a major component of the Martian surface, and its origin and evolution are important to understanding the planet. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a primary silica phase and is cogenetic with other sedimentary minerals. The sedimentary environment and source of the tridymite are discussed.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that the impact of these changes will vary across the world. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the expression of both the IL-12 and the IFN-γ receptor. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for sending signals to the muscles to move. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that support motor neurons. This method allows for rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will help in the development of new therapies for ALS.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota of the vector, I. scapularis, and enhances the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall polymer, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the Pygostylia, Jinguofortis, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the coupling between the different components of the system. In this paper, we show that the coupling between the troposphere and the stratosphere is important for the climate system, and that the coupling is stronger than previously thought. This has implications for the climate sensitivity of the climate system, which is the parameter that is used to estimate the future climate based on the past history of the climate system.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of colors, from red to blue, to camouflage themselves from predators and prey. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the underlying mechanism relies on the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our findings are of interest to biologists, chemists, and materials scientists. They also have implications for the study of evolution, developmental biology, and the design of materials.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations, which have different capacities to initiate tumors and to maintain the tumorigenic state. One of these populations, the cancer stem cells (CSCs), are responsible for the initiation of the tumor, and the other, the non-CSCs, are responsible for the maintenance of the tumor. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of a demethylase of mRNA, which increases the proportion of CSCs in breast cancer cells. This study provides a mechanism for the induction of CSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. This knowledge may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the ancient world. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Meishan volcanic ash bed, which marks the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and for the next 500 ka. The extinction and recovery are well established, but the relative roles of rate-dependent and state-dependent processes are not. This study provides a critical time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.
