The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and the maintenance of homeostasis. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the site of chronic inflammation, which is the main cause of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We use cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, and the lipid bilayer. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion with the viral membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform vaccine design. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even in the case of a single player. The result is also new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are infinite. The result is new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are countable and the payoffs are Borel-measurable.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population, and a 2.10-y reduction at birth and 3.05-y reduction at age 65 y for the Black and Latino populations, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the need for public health interventions to reduce the racial disparities in COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. (Show more)

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds, which is the basis of the chemical world. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, as a function of pressure, are consistent with the chemical behavior of elements, and that they can be used to predict and explain the chemistry of elements under pressure. This work is a major step forward in the understanding of the chemistry of elements under pressure.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of global fire activity over the past century. This has led to a warming of the climate, but with the potential to reverse this trend. We show that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate policy and for the management of fire in terrestrial ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal biology. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is linked to the maturation of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the acidification of the crypts, where the symbionts reside. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the timing of nutrient delivery. It also suggests that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of epithelium-associated microbial communities through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the timing of nutrient delivery. Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding society. However, the analysis of text data is challenging because of the large number of documents and the diversity of topics. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of text data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that our method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the Black Death and the spread of plague in Europe. It also has implications for the spread of other diseases in the past and in the future. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has led to the mass mortality of thousands of individuals. The disease is characterized by behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted vertically from parent to offspring. The virus is also detected in sediments and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it is spread by the environment. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars and highlights the importance of viruses in the functioning of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a new way. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia, with a recent settlement of the island. However, the distribution of the genetic contributions across the island shows that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While most sRNAs are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites on the target gene. This is an example of a protein that is not considered to be “coding” and demonstrates that the protein can have multiple functions.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapies for SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate into a quantitative variable. We propose a method to convert the original categorical data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting model is statistically robust and maintains similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how the resulting crop condition index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed method can be used to improve the accuracy of crop condition monitoring and yield forecasting systems worldwide.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by a variety of mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is simple, elegant, and generalizable to other domains of cognition.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because of the difficulty in obtaining samples from the fossil record. Here, we show that the molecular evolution of plastid genomes, the organelles that are the site of photosynthesis in plants, is linked to the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We demonstrate that the transition to parasitism is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes, which is linked to bursts of gene losses. Our findings provide a new perspective on the molecular evolution of plastid genomes and the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. They also suggest that the molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a dynamic process that is shaped by the evolutionary history of the organism. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in assessing the impact of climate change on local-scale droughts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized the study of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the formation of naturally occurring quasicrystals and the first nuclear explosion.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by pigments, the conversion of light energy to chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The biosynthesis of the pigments is a highly evolved process, and the enzymes that catalyze the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring are among the most productive enzymes on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, and neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (ASK1) pathway. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in multiple sclerosis. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest period on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that behavioral inflexibility resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and may lead to the development of new treatments. (Show more)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people around the world do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, but that individual-level variation in responsiveness is considerable. This work thus helps account for the prevalence of negative news content, and it also highlights the potential for more positive news content. The implications of these results for journalism are discussed.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that cause Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease with hematological abnormalities. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also highlights the importance of functional characterization of mutations in the context of a disease-causing gene. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is a result of both active release and endocytic uptake of aggregates. We demonstrate that the spread of aggregates is a noncell-autonomous process, and that the loss of vulnerable neurons can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in these neurons. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H). This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is critical for the cell cycle. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the cell cycle in a cell-line screen, and that this effect is rooted in the cell’s ability to meet the demand for the one-carbon unit. Thus, the cell’s ability to meet the demand for the one-carbon unit is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by a variety of genetic mutations. These mutations lead to the formation of intracellular inclusions that contain a large number of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a general feature of the disease. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

Cold atoms are a powerful tool for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum information processing and precision measurements. The ability to controllably couple atoms to the electromagnetic field is a key ingredient for many of these applications. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for controlling the interaction of cold atoms with light. The device can be fabricated from silicon nitride, a material with a wide range of applications in photonics and electronics. This device can be used to explore many-body physics with cold atoms and to engineer exotic quantum matter. The device can also be used for applications in quantum information processing and precision measurements.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using sequences from living organisms. However, viruses are often transmitted between hosts, and the evolution of viruses in the past is therefore difficult to study. Here we present the genomes of ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient DNA can be extracted from human remains, and that DNA from ancient humans can be sequenced. This opens up new possibilities for studying ancient pathogens. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a well-known phenomenon, but the rate of rise is not well known, and the reasons for the acceleration are not well understood. We provide a new estimate of the rate of rise, and we show that the acceleration is statistically significant. We also show that the acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it raises questions about the future of healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the location of the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole is able to react, while the isostere benzimidazole does not. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly identified coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to microbes associated with animals is a common feature of symbioses. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the activities of these microbes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to a symbiotic bacterium is the basis for the dynamic stability of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its specific, bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. We propose that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of epithelium-associated microbial communities through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in symbiosis. (Show more)

This study shows that teachers can be trained to adopt a more empathic mindset about student misbehavior. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in student suspensions. The findings have implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of DNA alkylation-based cancer therapy. Furthermore, the Pro-Gate loop identified in this work may be a potential target for the development of DNA alkylation-based cancer therapy.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia, and the virus is a potential threat to global health. To understand how MERS-CoV infects human cells, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that the first S proteolysis blocked the virus from infecting some cell types, but had little effect on other cell types. These findings suggest that the first S proteolysis expands virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and is a major contributor to land use change and biodiversity loss. The food system also has a major impact on population health. This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This has the potential to contribute to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and to improved population health. The study also provides evidence that nudging meal selection behavior can be achieved at low cost and with minimal disruption to the catering operation. This has implications for other domains where behavior change is important.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step forward in the understanding of the cell surface proteome and its role in cancer. It also provides a platform for the discovery of new cancer targets and biomarkers. The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. As a result, there has been a surge of interest in the effects of vote-by-mail programs. However, the evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail is mixed. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune system, and it is possible that this is due to the actions of accessory proteins such as ORF8. The structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides insight into how this protein may be interfering with the host immune response.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1). We also show that CRFR1 is expressed by astrocytes in the cortex and that CRF triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this disease. (Show more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. This is the idea of “selective inference”: We should only accept as true statements those that are supported by a preponderance of evidence. In the era of big data, however, it is difficult to avoid cherry-picking the data that we analyze. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. These methods can help us to avoid the problem of selective inference and to make more judicious use of the data that we have.

Endothelial cells are the most abundant cell type in the human body, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, including diabetes, cancer, and cardiovascular diseases. Therefore, the development of endothelial cells is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce endothelial development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces endothelial development in human cells, and that ETV2-induced endothelial development is associated with expression of multiple key endothelial development factors. Furthermore, ETV2-induced endothelial development provides vascularization in vivo. These results indicate that ETV2 is a promising therapeutic target for vascular diseases. The discovery of the ligand for the receptor tyrosine kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) has led to the development of a targeted therapy for anaplastic large cell lymphoma. In addition, the discovery of the ligand for the receptor tyrosine kinase leucocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK) has led to the development of a targeted therapy for anaplastic large cell lymphoma. Here, we show that these ligands are also involved in the development of zebrafish pigmentation. We also show that these ligands are involved in the development of zebrafish pigmentation.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular bases of T2D are well known, the mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still to be elucidated. Herein, we show that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for the maintenance of insulin secretion and for the regulation of insulin sensitivity. These findings establish a pathophysiological significance of STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These results also provide a rationale for the development of STING-targeted therapies for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a major evolutionary advantage. However, this also complicates the packaging of the genome into the viral particles. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that this interaction is a major determinant of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome.

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular cells. The objective of this study is to identify the mechanisms that regulate the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular cells. We found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular cells. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular cells and may lead to the development of a therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular link between plant and animal kingdoms, and may help in the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help in understanding the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host are likely to be important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help to inform the design of clinical trials and the development of treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the ongoing bleaching event, which is driven by global warming. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release is a direct consequence of the metabolic energy demand of the coral host and the resulting amino acid degradation. The resulting shift from symbiont to host carbon translocation is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In the absence of this barrier, the host is prone to systemic infections and death. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is able to sense the presence of tumors and to respond by activating a regenerative response. This response is dependent on the activity of the JNK pathway and the microbiome. We also show that the activity of the JNK pathway is critical for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a model for the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab reduces the capacity of PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small, remote volcano in West Antarctica. Extensive fallout from the eruptions has been found >2,800 km from the volcano, and the eruptions are identified as the source of halogen-rich volcanic aerosols in ice cores from West Antarctica. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly linked the eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can be used to link climate change to specific events in Earth history. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where food security is low. Our analysis highlights the need to protect river ecosystems from the impacts of overfishing and other threats, as well as to improve the sustainability of fisheries and ensure that fish are available to the poor. This study can help to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, and the reasons for this are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is reminiscent of a form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, they suggest that the mammalian CNS may have evolved a form of regeneration that is similar to conditioning, a phenomenon that produces robust regeneration in the adult CNS. Taken together, these findings provide a unique perspective on the evolution of the nervous system’s ability to regenerate.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In many organisms, the location of recombination events is determined by the binding sites of specific proteins. In this study, we describe the recombination landscape of the flowering plant Mimulus guttatus, which is known for its high levels of genetic variation. We find that recombination is distributed in a highly structured manner across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination. This is reminiscent of the recombination pattern in yeast and mice, suggesting that recombination initiation and polarity are ancient and conserved eukaryotic processes.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The identification of these networks is a major goal of neuroscience. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of resting state networks can be used to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We also show that the expression of these networks is altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this alteration is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This approach can be used to identify the organization of the brain in health and disease, and to assess the effects of treatment.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA. It is known to affect translation and stability of mRNA. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We demonstrate that NAD+ is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. These results define a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that the NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive therapy could prevent the development of diabetes complications. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Complications Study (EDIC Study) and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the development of behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study opens new perspectives in the understanding of the pathophysiology of alcohol dependence and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The tomato is a model system for studying the evolution of fruit flavor, and the identification of the genes responsible for the biosynthesis of the volatile compounds that contribute to the fruit flavor is a major step forward in understanding the evolution of fruit flavor.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning will be more severe than previously thought. This will have important implications for the management of ecosystems and the design of climate change mitigation strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a map of local space, which is represented by grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. How these cell types are organized in space is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings provide a more complete picture of the organization of the MEC map of space. They also provide a platform for future studies of the function of the MEC. Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), is able to induce flowering of the host plant in the rootless parasitic plant Cuscuta australis. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also provides a new approach to the study of flowering regulation, which may be applied to other plant processes. The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the dopamine system and its potential role in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to evaluate the quality of their connections, and by third-party listeners to evaluate the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for how we design social systems, and for how we design ourselves.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain’s ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind linguistic features over time. Plants are the primary source of food for the world, and the demand for food is expected to increase in the future. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanisms of gene silencing in plants and to develop strategies to deliver biomolecules to plants for gene silencing. Here, we report the delivery of biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and the gene silencing efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure geometry. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of gene silencing strategies in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world’s largest lakes are also the most vulnerable to nutrient pollution, which can fuel harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. We show that the nutrient inputs to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are driven by small streams that drain the surrounding watershed. These findings have implications for the management of nutrient pollution in large lakes worldwide.

We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a strong external force, and it is a consequence of the interplay between the chemical kinetics and the thermodynamics of the system.

The history of Earth’s climate is characterized by abrupt warming events, which are often associated with changes in the carbon cycle. However, the history of carbon perturbation events throughout Earth’s history is not well understood. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon cycle perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to a near doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. Modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. Our study provides insights into the history of carbon cycle perturbation events and their impact on the Earth system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of tropical deforestation-associated carbon emissions in the world. As a result, many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of fitness. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we show that the interaction of multiple sex determination genes can result in a modular system of sexual variation, where the same genotype can produce different phenotypes for different traits. This modular system of sexual variation can be maintained by the maintenance of sex determination alleles, the introgression of sex determination alleles, or the loss of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptor cells and by the pigment epithelium, respectively. The pigment epithelium is also challenged by the accumulation of lipid-derived reactive oxygen species-generating intermediates, which are photodegraded into damaging intermediates. We show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the balance between the generation and degradation of these intermediates. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, which is characterized by the accumulation of lipid-derived reactive intermediates. Our results suggest that iron may be a therapeutic target for this disease. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key driver of ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles, which are used for prey capture, has been linked to the evolution of other parts of the organism, and that these changes have allowed for the evolution of new prey types. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of predator specialization, and how it has shaped the structure of present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The earliest hominin fossils are incomplete, and the time interval between the appearance of the first hominids and the emergence of the distinctive human hand is poorly documented. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that preserves evidence for a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of the human hand. The discovery of this fossil also provides a new context for the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is a key enzyme in the folate cycle. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer cells in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of lymphoma cells, but is ineffective in blocking the growth of fibroblasts. This is important because the inhibition of the folate cycle is a common feature of cancer therapy, and thus the ability to target the folate cycle in one type of cancer, but not another, is important for the development of cancer therapeutics. Thus, this work is important for the development of cancer therapeutics.

The world is facing a food and nutrition crisis, and strategies to improve food and nutrition security continue to promote increasing food via agricultural intensification. However, little (if any) consideration is given to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals, despite a growing body of literature that shows that having access to these landscapes can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets and thus on their vitamin A status. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of considering the effects of deforestation on people’s diets in future studies and policy. This is particularly important in light of the current global trend toward deforestation.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a new species of sauropod in the Cretaceous of Argentina with a fixed foraging trail.
